children.name: be in the black
children.definition: /biː ɪn ðə ˈblæk/  if someone is in the black, they have earned more than they owe or have spent:
examples: có tiền
▪ The newly reorganized company is now in the black.
▪ Our oil and gas operations are comfortably in the black.
get something into the black
để cái gì đó có tiền
▪ We have to get our account into the black otherwise the bank will never give us a mortgage.

children.name: be in credit
children.definition: /biː ɪn ˈkredt/  if yourbankaccountis in credit, there is money in it and you do not owe the bank anything:
examples: vẫn còn tiền tín dụng
▪ I can see from my monthly bank statements whether I’m in credit or not.
remain/stay in credit
vẫn còn tiền tín dụng
▪ We offer free banking for customers whose accounts remain in credit.

children.name: keep your head above water
children.definition: /kiːp jɔːʳ ˌhed əbʌv ˈwɔːtəʳ/ informalto stay out of debt, although it is difficult to do this because you have very little money:
examples: ▪ Although I’ve been out of a job for three months, I’ve managed to keep my head above water.
▪ If I get this raise, we’ll just about keep our heads above water until next year.

children.name: solvent
children.definition: /ˈsɒlvəntǁˈsɑːl-/  earning enough money to not have to borrow or get into debt:
examples: ▪ We’ve been financially solvent for the last 5 years.
▪ Companies need to know that those with whom they are trading are solvent and can pay for goods and services supplied to them
solventadjective
(especially of companies) having enough money to pay all the money that is owed toother people
_Many insurance companies are under pressure to increase premiums tostaysolvent.

children.name: afloat
children.definition: /əˈfləʊt/
examples: if acompanyororganizationstays or remains afloat, it manages to keep operating because its debts are not so bad that it has to close;
if you keep a company or organization afloat, you stop it from getting into so much debt that it has to close:
không mắc nợ ai, chôi chảy
▪ It was the summer of 1991, and I was struggling hard to keep my business afloat.
▪ David Henry lent the company $1bn out of his own personal fortune in order to help it stay afloat.
▪ The organization remains afloat by renting out its skilled technicians to other companies.
afloatadjective[ after verb ]
having enough money to pay what you owe
_Many small businesses are struggling tostay/keepafloat.

children.name: get into debt X
children.definition: get into debt/ˌget ɪntə ˈdet/ mắc nợ
examples: ▪ The only way we could avoid getting into debt was to borrow money from our parents.
get heavily into debt
mắc nợ ngập đầu
begin to owe a lot of money
▪ They got so heavily into debt that they couldn’t even pay the interest on their loans.
get into debt
mắc nợ
start being in debt
▪ We got into debt when my wife lost her job.

children.name: run up a debt
children.definition: /ˌrʌn ʌp ə ˈdet/  to allow your debts to increase quickly, especially by continuing to spend money that you do not really have:
examples: chất đống nợ nần
▪ The government has run up an unrepayable debt of $6 billion.
run up debts
gây nợ nần chồng chất
▪ I’m not in the habit of running up debts.
▪ His son was wild and irresponsible and had run up debts that he expected his father to pay.
runsthupphrasal verb[ M ]DEBT
If you run upa debt,you do things which cause you to owe a large amount of money
_She stayed two weeks at the hotel and ran up abillwhich she couldn't pay.

children.name: default
children.definition: /dɪˈfɔːlt/  to not pay back a debt that you should pay according to the law:
examples: vỡ nợ, bùng
▪ If the purchaser defaults, the house becomes the property of the savings and loan company.default on
▪ In those days, anyone who defaulted on a loan was put in prison.
default[countable/uncountable noun]
sự vỡ nợ
▪ Loans are often refused to poorer borrowers because the risk of default is greater.
defaultverb[ I ] vỡ nợ không trả được
to fail to do something, such as pay a debt, that you legally have to do
_People who defaultontheir mortgage repayments may have their home repossessed.
( nhung nguoi vo no trong viec tra lai tien the chap co the bi chiem huu nha cua )
defaultnounFAIL vỡ nợ không trả được
[ C or U ] when you fail to do something, such as pay a debt that you legally have to
_Defaultsonloan repayments have reached 52,000 a month.
( su vo no trong viec tra lai tien cho vay da toi ….)
_Any defaultonyour mortgage repayments may mean you will lose your house.
_Since they refuse to reply, I think we've won the argumentbydefault
(= because of their failure to act) .
_Thedefaultrate(= the number of people failing to
do something) is estimated at 1 in 10 of tax payers.
( ti le vo no duoc danh gia tu mot den muoi nguoi fai tra tien thue )

children.name: to owe a lot of money
be deep/heavily in debt
children.definition: /biː ˌdiːp, ˌhevli ɪn ˈdet/  to owe a lot more money than you can pay:

children.name: nợ ngập mặt
examples: ▪ When my father died we discovered that he was heavily in debt.
▪ A disastrous attempt to expand left the airline deep in debt.

children.name: be deep/heavily in debt to
examples: ▪ The country is already heavily in debt to foreign banks.

children.name: be up to your neck/ears in debt
children.definition: /biː ˌʌp tə jɔːʳ ˌnek, ˌɪəʳz ɪn ˈdet/  informal to owe very large sums of money that you cannot pay:

children.name: nợ nần ngập đầu, ngập cổ
examples: ▪ Knowing that I was up to my ears in debt, Edwin offered to help me out.
▪ When their business failed, they found themselves up to their necks in debt.

children.name: owe
children.definition: /əʊ/  if you owe someone money, you have to pay them, either because you borrowed money from them or because you got something from them and have not yet paid for it:
examples: nợ
▪ The business collapsed, owing $50 million.
▪ His job was to phone people who owed money and demand immediate payment.
owe somebody something
▪ You still owe me $5
owe something to somebody
▪ We owe a lot of money to the bank.
owe somebody something for something
▪ How much do we owe you for the milk?
oweverb[ T ]HAVE DEBTS nợ
to need to pay or give something to someone because they have lent money to you,
_ [ + two objects ]I owe Janet ten pounds. ( toi no.. muoi ..)
_We still owe $1000onour car (= We still need to pay $1000 before we own our car) .

children.name: be in debt
children.definition: /biː ɪn ˈdet/  if you are in debt, you owe a lot of money and you have difficulty paying it:
examples: mắc nợ
▪ The helpline offers financial advice to people who are in debt.
be £1000/$2000 etc in debt
nợ 1000 bảng Anh/ 2000 đô la ....
owe that amount
▪ The report showed that most students were over £1000 in debt on leaving college.
be heavily in debt
nợ ngập mặt
owe a very large amount of money
▪ Karen was forced to give up her job to look after her daughter, and the family is now heavily in debt.

children.name: be in the red
children.definition: /biː ɪn ðə ˈred/  to have spent more than you have earned :

children.name: thâm hụt ngân sách, mắc nợ
examples: ▪ My son’s bank account is usually in the red.
▪ After five quarters in the red, the business will soon be profitable.

children.name: be deep in the redowe a lot more than you have
examples: ▪ Overseas payments could keep the country deep in the red for the next decade.

children.name: be in the redinformal
examples: If you or your bank account are in the red, you owe money to the bank.

children.name: IOU
children.definition: /ˌaɪ əʊ ˈjuː/  a note that you write saying that you owe someone money or that you will pay for something later - often used byjournalistsas aninformalword for a legal agreement in which one business or organization owes another money:
examples: giấy nợ
▪ Essentially, a bond is an IOU.
give somebody an IOU
ghi giấy nợ cho ai đó
▪ There was anger among farmers, who were being given IOUs instead of cash for their crops.
IOUnoun[ C ] giấy nợ
abbreviation for I owe you:a written promiseto pay back a debt
_Here's an IOU for the fiver you lent me. I'll pay you back on Monday.

children.name: borrowings
children.definition: /ˈbɒrəʊɪŋzǁˈbɑː-, ˈbɔː-/  thetotalamount of money that acompanyhas borrowed and owes - used inbusinesscontexts:

children.name: khoản vay
examples: ▪ Borrowings at the end of the year amounted to nearly $27 million.
▪ The company was now so large it could increase its borrowings to almost any figure it chose.

children.name: overdraft
children.definition: /ˈəʊvəʳdrɑːftǁ-dræft/  an amount of money that you owe to yourbankwhen you have spent more money that you had in your bank account:
examples: số tiền chi trột
▪ I’ve already got an enormous overdraft.
a £100/$1500 etc overdraft
▪ When he left college, he had a $3000 overdraft.
overdraftnoun[ C ] số tiền chi trội; số tiền rút quá số tiền gửi trong một tài khoản (ngân hàng)
an amount of money that a customer with a bank account is temporarily allowed to owe to the bank, or the agreement which allows this
_torun up/pay offan overdraft
_The bank offers overdraftfacilities.

children.name: debt
children.definition: /det/  money that you owe, especially a large amount:món nợ
examples: ▪ Debt is one of the main social problems of our time.
debt of
món nợ
▪ The government now has debts of $2.5 billion.
pay off/repay a debtpay all the money that you owe
trả sạch nợ
▪ It took us three years to pay off all our debts.
write off a debtagree that it will not and does not need to be repaid
xóa nợ
▪ He protected less profitable state farms by writing off their debts.
foreign debtmoney owed by foreign countries
nợ nước ngoài
▪ To pay the interest on our foreign debt, we will have to import less.
a bad debta debt that will never be repaid
món nợ khó đòi
▪ Lenders must try and protect themselves against bad debts.
debtnoun[ C or U ]nợ
something, especially money, which is owed to someone else,orthe state of owing something
_He managed topay offhis debts in two years.
_The firmran uphuge debts.
_They areindebtto(= owe money to) the bank.
_Heran/got intodebt (= borrowed money) after he lost his job.
_The company isdeep indebt (= owes a lot of money) .
national debtnoun[ C usually singular ] (US alsopublic debt)nợ quốc gia
the total amount of moneythat is owed by a country's government
bad debtnoun[ C ] ( mon no kho doi )
a debtthat is not likely to be paid
_The bank expects to lose £703 million of last year's profits as a result of bad debts.

children.name: liabilities
children.definition: /ˌlaɪəˈbɪlɪtiz, ˌlaɪəˈbɪlətiz/  the debts that a company, government etc is legally responsible to pay - used especially in legal and business contexts:nợ
examples: ▪ The chart shows the movements in the company’s liabilities and assets during a particular trading period.
▪ US external net liabilities rose throughout the 1980s.
liabilitiesspecialized tiền nợ, khoản nợ
debts
_The business has liabilities of £2 million.

children.name: when debts have not been paid
unpaid
children.definition: /ˌʌnˈpeɪd◂/ không thanh toán, không trả
examples: ▪ She left a number of unpaid bills when she went back home.
▪ The card holder is liable for any unpaid debts.
go/remain unpaid
vẫn không thanh toán, không trả
▪ Last month they owed £500. This went unpaid and the arrears will total £1000 by December.
unpaidadjective chưa được thanh toán, chưa được trả
describes a debt, tax, etc. that has not been paid
_$50 000 in unpaid taxes

children.name: due
children.definition: /djuːǁduː/  an amount of money that is due should be paid now:đến hạn trả
examples: ▪ The computer printout shows the name and address of the buyer, the quantity ordered and the amount due.
▪ Million dollar interest payments will be due in two years.
dueadjectiveOWED đến kỳ đòi; đến hạn trả (nợ...)
owed as a debt or as a right
_The rent is due (= should be paid) at the end of the month.
( tien thue muon den han tra vao cuoi thang )
_Fifty pounds ismainly UKduetome/mainly USdue me by the people I
worked for last month. (= the necessary)care and attention.
_bill due on May 1st
hối phiếu trả vào ngay mồng 1 tháng 5.
_fall (become) due
đến kỳ phải trả; đến hạn
_my rent isn't due till Wednesday
đến thứ tư mới tới hạn tôi phải trả tiền thuê nhà

children.name: outstanding
children.definition: /aʊtˈstændɪŋ/  an amount of money that is outstanding is still owed to someone:chưa trả
examples: ▪ The government plans to reduce its outstanding debt, freeing capital for investment.
▪ The amount outstanding on your house mortgage and any other loans will be counted as liabilities.
outstandingadjectiveNOT FINISHED chưa trả
not yet paid, solved or done
_$450 million in outstanding debts

children.name: owing
children.definition: /ˈəʊɪŋ/  an amount of money that is owing is still left to be paid:còn nợ
examples: ▪ The total amount owing at the end of ten years will be over $20,000.
▪ Most of the money has been repaid but there is still £5 owing.
owingadjective[ after verb ]UK còn nợ
still to be paid
_We have several hundred pounds owingonour car.
( chung toi co .. con fai tra cho chiec xe cua chung toi )

children.name: the amount that a bank charges on money that it lends
lending rate
children.definition: noun( alsointerest rate) mainly UK

children.name: the amountthat a bank charges on money that it lends
examples: _Banks have raised their lending rates by 2%.

children.name: interest rate
children.definition: lending ratenoun( also) mainly UK

children.name: the amountthat a bank charges on money that it lends
examples: _Banks have raised their lending rates by 2%.

children.name: to owe money to a bank
be overdrawn
children.definition: /biː ˌəʊvəʳˈdrɔːn/  to owe money to yourbankbecause you have spent more than you had in your bank account:
examples: rút tiền quá mức
▪ I’m always overdrawn at the end of the month.
be $100/£200 etc overdrawn
▪ The bank wrote to tell us we were $500 overdrawn.
overdrawnadjective rút quá nhiều số tiền gởi trong một tài khoản (ngân hàng)
having taken more money out of your bank account than the account contained, or (of a bank account) having hadmore money taken from it than was originally in it
_They were overdrawnby£150, so they couldn't write any cheques.
_The account was overdrawn.

children.name: be in the red
children.definition: /biː ɪn ðə ˈred/  to have spent more than you have earned:

children.name: thâm hụt tiền,thâm hụt ngân sách, mắc nợ ( chi nhiều hơn kiếm được )
examples: ▪ My son’s bank account is usually in the red.
▪ After five quarters in the red, the business will soon be profitable.

children.name: be deep in the redowe a lot more than you have
examples: ▪ Overseas payments could keep the country deep in the red for the next decade.

children.name: be in the redinformal
examples: If your bank account are in the red, you owe money to the bank.

children.name: to owe money to sb that should be paid regularly
be in arrears
children.definition: /biː ɪn əˈrɪəʳz/  to have not paid money, such as rent, that you should pay at aparticulartimeeverymonth, year etc - used especially inofficialorlegaldocuments:
examples: bị trễ tiền
▪ Two out of three tenants are in arrears.
be 6 months/3 weeks etc in arrears
bị trễ tiền 6 tháng/3 tuần ...
▪ The number of mortgages over 12 months in arrears is rising.
be £1000/$200 etc in arrears
bị trễ 1000 bảng Anh/200 đô la...
▪ The country is reported to be $6 billion in arrears on its $115 billion debt.
be in arrears with/on
bị trễ tiền với
▪ The courts can obtain payments for those in arrears with consumer credit agreements.
in arrears ( keo dai/ tri hoan )
owing money that should have been paid in the past
_My account is badly in arrears.
_They are in arrearson/withtheir mortgage payments.

children.name: be behind with U
children.definition: be behind with/biː bɪˈhaɪnd wɪð/  to have not paid an amount that you should payregularlyat the right time:
examples: nợ trả sau
▪ I have no money in my bank account, and I’m behind with my rent.
fall behind with something
nợ trả sau
▪ Unemployment is the major cause of people falling behind with their mortgage repayments.
get behindphrasal verb
to fail to pay as much money as you should by a particular time
_She got behindwithher mortgage and the house was repossessed.
( anh ay da… tien the chap va ngoi nha da bi lay di )

children.name: call sth in
children.definition: callsthinphrasal verb đòi (nợ )

children.name: If abankcalls in money, it demands that you pay back the money it has lent to you
examples: _He needs to make the business work before the bank calls in the loan.

children.name: write sth off
children.definition: writesthoffphrasal verbMONEYxóa nợ

children.name: to acceptthat an amount of money has been lost or that a debt will not be paid
examples: _The World Bank is being urged to write off debts from developing countries.

children.name: neither owing nor owed any money
straight
children.definition: adjectiveNOT OWING MONEY

children.name: informalneither owing nor owed any money
examples: _You bought the tickets, so if I pay for the taxi, we'll be straight.

children.name: to agree that money that sb owes does not have to be paid
write off
children.definition: /ˌraɪt ˈɒf/  to officially say that a company or country no longer has to pay a debt, especially because they will probably never be able to pay it:xóa nợ
examples: write off something
xóa nợ cái gì đó
▪ European governments were persuaded to write off the republic’s largest debts.
▪ A number of the company’s debts were written off even before they went bankrupt.
write something off
xóa nợ cái gì đó
▪ We’ll never see that money again so we might as well write it off.
write-off/ˈraɪt ɒf/ [countable noun]
sự xóa nợ
▪ The corporation is still suffering from $350 million in losses and write-offs amounts of money written off.
